 There are wondeful social effects of Christianity. Evolution has none.
 Darwin warned against allowing "the weak members of civilised societies [to] propagate their kind"
 "With savages, the weak in body or mind are soon eliminated; and those that survive commonly exhibit a vigorous state of health. We civilised men, on the other hand, do our utmost to check the process of elimination; we build asylums for the imbecile, the maimed, and the sick; we institute poor-laws; and our medical men exert their utmost skill to save the life of every one to the last moment. There is reason to believe that vaccination has preserved thousands, who from a weak constitution would formerly have succumbed to small-pox. Thus the weak members of civilised societies propagate their kind. No one who has attended to the breeding of domestic animals will doubt that this must be highly injurious to the race of man. It is surprising how soon a want of care, or care wrongly directed, leads to the degeneration of a domestic race; but excepting in the case of man himself, hardly any one is so ignorant as to allow his worst animals to breed." (Darwin, Charles R. [English naturalist and founder of the modern theory of evolution], "The Descent of Man and Selection in Relation to Sex," [1871], John Murray: London, Second Edition, 1922, reprint, pp.205-206) [top]
 
 "Haeckel was the chief apostle of evolution in Germany. Nordenskiold (1929) argues that he was even more influential than Darwin in convincing the world of the truth of evolution. ... But, as Gasman argues, Haeckel's greatest influence was, ultimately, in another, tragic direction-national socialism. His evolutionary racism; his call to the German people for racial purity and unflinching devotion to a "just" state; his belief that harsh, inexorable laws of evolution ruled human civilization and nature alike, conferring upon favored races the right to dominate others; the irrational mysticism that had always stood in strange communion with his brave words about objective science-all contributed to the rise of Nazism. The Monist League that he had founded and led, though it included a wing of pacifists and leftists, made a comfortable transition to active support for Hitler." (Gould, Stephen J. [Professor of Zoology and Geology, Harvard University], "Ontogeny and Phylogeny," Belknap Press: Cambridge MA, 1977, pp.77-78).

I have a belief in the Bible that allows me to accept it as a moral, spiritual, and theistic guide--maybe not by itself, but there are many religious texts that have the same message at their core--without having to sacrifice a logical, rational understanding of the world around me. 
 
 I accept the Bible and I accept evolution; the fact that you are not able to understand things the way I do in no way imperils my soul.

 Evolution is your god.'The most devastating thing though that biology did to Christianity was the discovery of biological evolution. Now that we know that Adam and Eve never were real people the central myth of Christianity is destroyed. If there never was an Adam and Eve there never was an original sin. If there never was an original sin there is no need of salvation. If there is no need of salvation there is no need of a saviour. And I submit that puts Jesus, historical or otherwise, into the ranks of the unemployed. I think that evolution is absolutely the death knell of Christianity.'
 
 
 
 
 A religion is essentially an attitude to the world as a whole. Thus evolution, for example, may prove as powerful a principle to co-ordinate men's beliefs and hopes as God was in the past. Such ideas underlie the various forms of Rationalism, the Ethical movement and scientific Humanism.'
 
 'Humanism: An outlook that places man and his concerns at the centre of interest. Modern Humanism, which does away with traditional Christianity, is characterised by its faith in the power of human beings to create their own future, collectively and personally.'
 
 In other words, evolution = religion. That is, people (not God) set whatever rules they want. In practice, this usually becomes 'might makes right', including the tyranny of the majority.

 Doesn't have to be all or nothing really.

It would be like me asking why are the Hadeeth's useful? The subject interest's me but the question of why they are useful or not would never cross my mind.

 "Other people have clearly demonstrated to me that it is silly to apply physical evidence to question whether or not god exists, I do not do it."
 Try thinking for yourself. Even Darwin saw the design in nature.

Some people I can accept that with but your interest in the Bible indicates loudly to me you would like to believe it is true.

You do believe however in the existence of god's . That makes no sense to me. 
 
 The New Testament refutes evolution every bit as much as Genesis because of the words of Jesus Christ and all of the apostles.
 
 The patent argument of evolutionist is that the Old Testament is a myth because it contradicts the work of chaos and cronos. My point of my post was the whole Bible does so and it must be completely disregarded or rewritten to fit evolution. The atheist ever since Darwin's prime political example knew they must destroy Christianity to sell evolution. It has to be done slowly. Darwin knew this and was careful how far he pushed. His own words were his faith disappeared slowly and painlessly.

 If you find out to late that you are wrong remember that Jesus said you are with me or against me , you gather souls to me or you scatter them.
 I will pray for you. Life does not have to be so empty as to believe you are a mistake of nature and it never has to end.

That is not possible. You must reject the words of Jesus Christ to accept evolution. 
 If you do not believe in the God of the Bible then you have created your own god.
 It's a free country , you can worship Jerry Lewis if you like.

 
 No, no, no. Where does Christ say "thou shalt not accept evolution?" Why do you insist on the entire Bible being indisputable fact? I find it so much more miraculous that the Bible may have a wonderful subtext that means much more than the sum of its words.
 
 Take for example the story of the loaves and fishes. If you read it just as a story, then you have just read a story about a magician who converted some bread and fish into a feast for thousands; if you read it as allegory, it is a metaphor for how the simple word of God is able to fulfill the souls of all the people. 
 
 If we try to read the Bible with a strict interpretation, we are in danger of choking on the details. Why bother to develop a pseudoscientific proof of how a little bread and fish could be distributed in such a way that they could feed thousands when we can better spend our time in contemplation of how God fulfills us spiritually? Strict biblical constructionism only leaves you staring at the pages, not absorbing the Word.
 
 And I rather enjoy Jerry Lewis, but I don't worship him. Nor do I worship evolution, gravity, or the pythagorean theory. They don't provide spiritual fulfillment; I don't expect or want them to. They do provide a rational and disinterested explanation of the world as it is. I don't look to them for spiritual subtext or guidance because they don't offer it, regardless of what you attempt to say. There is no widespread Machiavellian (you would say Darwinian) attempt by people who believe in evolution to subvert Christianity. 
 
 I believe that man is meant to trust his rational abilities, while at the same time contemplating his spiritual existence. The Bible cultivates this contemplative spiritual investigation, while science cultivates the rational abilities of man. Insinuating a fundamental conflict between the two only leaves us in danger of being less than whole human beings.
